title: John Biehl
text:
John Henry Biehl del Río (; born 26 August 1939) is a <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an lawyer, <a href="political%20scientist">political scientist</a>, and diplomat who served as the <a href="cabinet-level">cabinet-level</a> <a href="Ministry%20General%20Secretariat%20of%20the%20Presidency%20%28Chile%29">Minister Secretary-General of the Presidency</a> for <a href="Eduardo%20Frei%20Ruiz-Tagle">Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle</a>'s administration.
Early life.
Biehl is of <a href="Danish%20people">Danish</a> ancestry. He studied <a href="law">law</a> at the <a href="Pontifical%20Catholic%20University%20of%20Valpara%C3%ADso">Pontifical Catholic University of Valparaíso</a> in his home city, and later <a href="Economic%20development">national development</a> in the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, and finally <a href="political%20science">political science</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Essex">University of Essex</a>, where he received his <a href="Master%27s%20degree">Master's degree</a>.
Biehl was the founder and director of the Institute of Political Science at the <a href="Pontifical%20Catholic%20University%20of%20Chile">Pontifical Catholic University of Chile</a>.
Diplomatic and political career.
Although Biehl had never registered for any <a href="political%20party">political party</a>, he is considered more of a <a href="Christian%20Democrat%20Party%20of%20Chile">Christian Democrat</a> due to his <a href="exile">exile</a> after the <a href="1973%20Chilean%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">1973 Chilean coup d'état</a> and <a href="Chile%20under%20Pinochet">Pinochet's rise to power</a>. He gained diplomatic experience acting as an advisor to various governments. These included that of <a href="%C3%93scar%20Arias">Óscar Arias</a> in <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a>, where he worked as a policymaker and speechwriter; "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" referred to him as Arias' "closest confidant" and "alter ego". Biehl also led the successful campaign for Arias' 1987 <a href="Nobel%20Peace%20Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>. As a <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> official working for the <a href="United%20Nations%20Development%20Programme">United Nations Development Programme</a> (UNDP), Biehl also lived in <a href="Honduras">Honduras</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, and <a href="Panama">Panama</a>. However, Biehl was forced out of the UN in 1987 after demands by the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> government, due to unhappiness in the <a href="Reagan%20administration">Reagan administration</a> over his part in Arias' opposition to funding of the <a href="Contras">Contras</a>.
During the administration of <a href="President%20of%20Chile">President</a> <a href="Eduardo%20Frei%20Ruiz-Tagle">Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle</a>, Biehl was appointed Chile's ambassador to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. He was then appointed <a href="Ministry%20General%20Secretariat%20of%20the%20Presidency%20%28Chile%29">Minister Secretary-General of the Presidency</a>, a cabinet-level role which serves as the link between the <a href="executive%20branch">executive</a> and the <a href="legislative%20branch">legislative</a>. He served from 1998 to 1999.
After the government.
Currently, Biehl works for the <a href="Organization%20of%20American%20States">Organization of American States</a> (OAS), in the Department of Political Affairs. Among other things, he was named by the <a href="Secretary%20General%20of%20the%20Organization%20of%20American%20States">Secretary General</a>, fellow Chilean <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Miguel%20Insulza">José Miguel Insulza</a>, <a href="special%20envoy">special envoy</a> to direct the mission to observe the regional and presidential elections in <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a>, conducted March 5 through November 5, 2006.
